bibl.title: Letter from George M. Kober to Howard A. Kelly, February 20, 1901

div1.p: Kober sends Kelly extracts of a report, written by himself, entitled “Flies in the transmission of Typhoid”

div1.head: Letter from George M. Kober to Howard A. Kelly, February 20, 1901
div1.opener:
Ackn.
1600 T Street N.W.
February 20, 1901
Dr. Howard H. Kelly,
1418 Euteno Place
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Kelly.
div1.p:
In reply to your inquiry for
Reprints on “Flies in the transmission of
Typhoid” I regret to say that I have never
had any Reprints; my Report on the Prevalence
of Typhoid Fever in the District of Columbia was
published in the Health Officers Report D.C. for
1895, and it is possible that Dr Woodward may
be able to mail you a Copy of the Report, al-
though he informed me some time ago, that
these Reports had been all distributed; My Report
was based upon 500 cases selected at random from
among those occurring in the District between July 1st
& October 31st 1895.

In speaking of the mode of dissemination on
p: 260, I say “Prof. Finkler of Bonn a very
competent observer, believes that the disease may
be communicated by intimate contact, living in
the same room, or breathing the same air and
accounts in this way for a number of outbreaks in
his section. In 1886 a young woman who had
been called to one hamlet to nurse her children,
returned to her home was taken sick with typhoid
fever, communicated the disease to her Nurse
and subsequently 50 other cases developed which
could not be traced to soil pollution or infected
water x x x
2
I have found similar instances in my present
investigation, but it is practically impossible to say
whether in these cases the germs were conveyed
through the fingers or through the air or by means
of flies infecting the food.”

On p: 266 in speaking of a group of typhoid fever
cases I say, “All of the cases on Blacksburg
road and vicinity except those on Lewis Street,
occurred in houses supplied with boxprivies. It
was admitted, that the stools from typhoid fever
patients residing on Blacksburg Road were
thrown upon the ground without disinfection,
and as the drainage from these houses is in
the direction of Trinidad Avenue and King Kised
the residents there were exposed to infection. There
is abundant evidence of unlawful surface
pollution and stagnant kitchen slops may be
observed on Trinidad Avenue in a number of
places, and as the germs find a suitable soil
in such surroundings it is possible, that the flies
which abound wherever surface pollution exists
may carry the germs into the houses and con-
taminate the food or drink. s & There was
nothing in common in the milk supply of the
different houses, and, as there was no well liable
to contamination from the first source, it is not
improbable that the infection was conveyed in
the manner indicated.”

On p: 270 in speaking of a group of cases in
adjoining houses on I Street N. E. I say,
“The first case occurred on July 28th at No
1016 -- the next case August 10th in No 1014, fol-
lowed by two others cases in the same house Aug
22nd and Septbr 15th. Another case occurred at
No 1010 October 24” There was nothing in common
with the milk supply, and the fact that the cases
The houses in the entire row are supplied with
box privies and the general surroundings are very
unsanitary. There was nothing in common with
the milk supply, and the fact that the cases
occurred at considerable intervals indicates with
more or less certainty that the first case was a
focus of infection; but how the germs were carried
unless by flies, or through the air, is a matter
impossible to determine.

On p. 271 -- reference is made to cases occurring
in houses located near places defiled with excite-
ment, or where typhoid dejecta had been deposited
and that there is much reason for assuming, that
infection was carried from the unsanitary conditions
referred to.

On p. 280 in speaking of Box Privies I say
“These boxes, even if there were no wells are still
a source of danger in so far as they favor the
transmission of germs by means of infected flies
nor can the possibility be ignored that these organisms
in leaky or overflowing boxes may reach the upper
layer of the sick and with pulverized dust, gain access
to the system.”

I have made these Extracts fearing that you may not be able to secure a Copy
of the Report for permanent retention, you can doubtless borrow a Copy and verify
the excerpts.- I presume you have sent Dr. L. O. Howard's Monograph published
by the Washington Academy of Sciences.
div1.closer: Very Truly Yours Geo. M. Kober;
